stream_context.summary: Kaze live-builds Course 13, an ice-covered mansion level. He tests new platforming tech, lays out rooms, and solves how players will obtain the first star by reworking level geometry and mechanics.

development_findings.summary: Introduced a new appearing-platform effect that uses a seamless snowflake texture; platforms now ‘grow’ smoothly instead of popping in.
development_findings.quote: They now grow first and then they slowly grow into the whole thing. It's not as abrupt anymore.

development_findings.summary: Re-designed level entry so the player sees Star 1 immediately: a star frozen behind an ice wall framed by two spiral stair/slide structures.
development_findings.quote: I want that when you enter the level, you immediately see the first star… it’s frozen behind the ice here.

development_findings.summary: Abandoned swinging-chandelier puzzle for Star 1; settled on rolling a large snowball down a slide to smash the ice wall.
development_findings.quote: Maybe a snowball on a platform like in Snowman's Land… you push the snowball and you follow the snowball and land right on the star.

development_findings.summary: Still plans to add swinging ice chandeliers as moving platforms elsewhere; will restrict swing to one axis to avoid quaternion math and keep player control readable.
development_findings.quote: If I could just lock it into one axis… that would be a lot easier to program and easier for the player.

development_findings.summary: Outlined full star list: 1) Ice-wall snowball puzzle, 2) Snowman Cave path, 3) Big Raven rooftop boss, 4) Cold Haze Room, 5) Reds in outside area, 6) Hidden 8-bit pipe segment.
development_findings.quote: Reds in the outside area and the 8-bit pipe somewhere… still have to plan the 8-bit pipe in somehow.

development_findings.summary: Cinematic concept for Raven boss: moon slowly eclipsed, screen goes black, two glowing eyes appear before battle on castle roof.
development_findings.quote: Out of the pure black you see two eyes just opening up and that's the boss intro.

development_findings.summary: Level design goal is open-ended but readable: many inter-connected routes that all funnel to major objectives.
development_findings.quote: The idea is just that every path kind of leads to a goal.

development_findings.summary: Memory, not raw performance, expected to be limiting; destructible ice penguin statues will be separate objects to conserve memory budget.
development_findings.quote: I think we are not going to run into performance issues but rather memory issues in this level.

development_findings.summary: Current power-ups coded: Ice Cap (cold immunity), Bomb Cap, Wing Cap, Cloud Cap; Fire Flower intentionally excluded.
development_findings.quote: We’re not adding the fire-flower power-up for one star—that would be silly.

development_findings.summary: Repository for current build is private; older versions are public. Fast64 + Blender remain core tools; standard in-game audio target is 32 kHz.
development_findings.quote: The newest one is not public… maybe next time I release a mini-hack I will make it public again.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is frustrated with Windows 10/11 updates and is seriously considering switching to Linux to avoid forced changes.
context_findings.quote: I think I might become a Linux user in the new year… every time software updates it introduces new bugs.

context_findings.summary: He is dealing with knee pain, making it hard to sit and forcing an early end to the stream.
context_findings.quote: The knee pain is getting pretty bad and I need to get up, so I will be seeing you guys some other time.

context_findings.summary: Caffeine withdrawal and general fatigue noted during stream.
context_findings.quote: Here’s your caffeine and you didn’t just begin to feel so bad… I abused it today.

context_findings.summary: Design philosophy: gameplay first, theming second; no NPC dialogue, minimal puzzles, focus on ‘playground’ platforming.
context_findings.quote: The theming should be secondary to the gameplay… you don’t talk to NPCs in this game.

context_findings.summary: Views ROM-hack as future marketing for an original indie title; sees marketing as the majority of game-dev battle.
context_findings.quote: This will be pretty insane advertisement for whenever I do my own game… marketing seems to be basically 90 % of the equation.

context_findings.summary: Pride in self-invented seamless snowflake pattern; values personal creativity.
context_findings.quote: I invented this pattern. I needed a seamless snowflake pattern that repeats.

biobak.summary: Supplied a low-poly ice penguin statue model with effective vertex colors; Kaze plans to use it as a destructible object.
biobak.quote: Let me place one of these in the castle… it looks very, very nice.

biobak.summary: Accidentally (or purposely) left duplicate triangles in a model, leading Kaze to clean up six excess faces.
biobak.quote: Did Biobak sneak in a triangle? …either way that’s six triangles down.

zeina.summary: Active in chat; offered a ‘banger idea’ that influenced the staircase/slide layout, earning public credit from Kaze.
zeina.quote: You missed Lilaa, I’m very sorry… Lilaa actually had the banger idea today and you missed it.

zeina.summary: Domestic context noted: she was moving furniture during stream; casual interaction highlights personal/professional blend.
zeina.quote: You guys can’t hear it but I think she’s taking the house apart… you’re moving things together, your mom’s here.

key_stories.title: Cracking the Ice-Wall Star
key_stories.summary: Kaze wants Star 1 to be seen immediately but unreachable. He experiments with mirrors, bomb caps, chandeliers, and finally designs a snowball slide that smashes the frozen wall.
key_stories.challenge: Make the first star visually obvious yet initially inaccessible.
key_stories.process: Tried mirror reflection, considered bomb cap and swinging chandelier mechanics, re-shaped room for space, added large rollable snowball inspired by Snowman’s Land.
key_stories.outcome: Settled on snowball mechanic; geometry updated to accommodate slide path.
key_stories.key_quote: You push the snowball and you follow the snowball and land right on the star.

key_stories.title: From Pop-In to Snowflake Growth
key_stories.summary: The original appearing-platforms felt abrupt. Kaze creates a seamless snowflake texture and rewrites the effect so platforms scale up smoothly, matching the icy theme.
key_stories.challenge: Abrupt platform pop-in broke visual cohesion.
key_stories.process: Designed hex-based snowflake pattern, adjusted shader/timing so geometry scales before becoming solid.
key_stories.outcome: Platforms now ‘grow’, giving a polished and thematic visual.
key_stories.key_quote: They now grow first and then… it’s not as abrupt anymore.

key_stories.title: The Swinging Chandelier Dilemma
key_stories.summary: Kaze envisions ice chandeliers that swing when Mario shifts weight, doubling as moving platforms. Technical limitations (quaternion math, camera readability) force a redesign.
key_stories.challenge: Implement believable multi-axis swing without heavy math or confusing players.
key_stories.process: Explores free-swing vs single-axis constraints, considers chain collision and introduction room.
key_stories.outcome: Mechanic kept for later rooms with motion locked to one axis; removed from Star 1 puzzle.
key_stories.key_quote: If I could just lock it into one axis… that would be a lot easier to program and easier for the player.
